intro: Brassica cossoniana, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mustard, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring alternate, linear to lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. Brassica cossoniana is often found in disturbed soils and can be a weed in agricultural settings.
